transcripts.text: Every student who's an admitted freshman at Hillsdale College, we send them a copy of Aristotle's Ethics.  That's a frightening thing to do.  Everybody knows that Aristotle's a little complicated, right?  I brought my toy Aristotle here this morning so you can see how friendly he is.

The reason that I wanted to take this course on the ethics was, first of all, I think Dr.  Aron's an amazing teacher.  I learned so much from him.  And I knew that he would describe Aristotle's ethics in a way that was both profound but applicable.
Because it's not just that you're free to choose.  It's also that your choices matter very much, and they make you what you are.

Through the ethics, we learn that with time, if we really want this, through practice, through trying again and again, even when we fail, we can become the people we want to be, the people we know that we can be.
So it's not just some random philosophy book that has these high and mighty things that are never going to apply.  It's something that you can do now.

It is the greatest self-help book for understanding how to be happy, how to be good in this life.  Fielding questions from Dr.  Arnn regarding a book that he has read at least 44 times is more than a little bit intimidating.
Dominic Whelan over there just said that he didn't get that part, so I would like to invite him to just sit here through this class and contemplate.
Especially since I've read it a grand total of once.
He definitely keeps you on your toes, doesn't let you get away with any imprecise answers.
Okay, that had all the elements, but it was a little sloppy.
I think it's really important to read Nicomachean Ethics because it actually is able to lay out in this direct and systematic way what specifically it means to be good and how to do it.

It's a way to find out what we all really want to know.  Everybody wants to know how to be good.  Everybody wants to do the right thing.  So this is really the most natural course, the best class that you can take.
And I think if you stick with it, it gets more beautiful as you go along.
The things it says are eternal.  It's one of the greatest books with probably one of the greatest Aristotle teachers alive.
You'll find out that if you live a very good life, pleasures will come to you beyond imagining, but you have to earn it first.
